title: 中風後會診復健
content:
This is a 68 year old female with underlying of
# Hypertension

The patient was admitted under the diagnosis of acute ischmic stroke. Under relatively stable vital sign, we need your help for rehabilitation. Thank you.

[Neurological examination]
E4V5M6
Pupil reflex 3+/3+
EOM full, VF intact, ptosis(-), nystagmus(-)
Facial sensation: onion skin normal, light touch symmetrical
Facial palsy(-)
Tongue deviation(-)
Dysarthria(-)
[Muscle power] RUL5, RLL5, LUL5, LLL5
[DTR] L4++/++
Babinski(R/L): withdraw/withdraw
FNF: no dysmetria
HKS: no dysmetria
Light touch: intact
Pinprick: intact

title: Central facial palsy with mild numbness NIHSS=2
content:
A 73 y/o male has past history of 
# BPH
# CAD under aspirin use
# Dyslipidemia under Crestor use
# Hypertension

He has had right facial palsy with drooling and speak indistinctly since 10/20 morning when having breakfast. Assoicated symtpoms included mild numbness at right cheek. He denied fever, nausea or vomiting, blurred vision, slurred speech, head trauma, weakness or loss of conscious. 

LKNT: 10/20 08:00
[Patient baseline status] GCS456, pre-Stroke mRS:0
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert 
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
No rash or shingles noted 
facial palsy (+, right central palsy)
No tounge deviation
Motor:
 - upper  (R/L: [5/5])
 - lower  (R/L: [5/5])
DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
Babinski sign: R/L: down/down
Sensory: Pinprick: right V2 dermatome had mild hypoethesia
NIHSS = 000 001 0000 01000 = 2

Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage or definite acute infarction seen

Impression:
# Central facial palsy, suspected left subcortical infarction

Suggestion:
# Aspirin 3# STAT + 1# QD; Clopidogrel 4# STAT + 1# QD
# We have explained the clinical coarse to the patient and reminded the patient to warn about the red flag sign
# Suggest Admission (#11294)

title: Stroke stardard template
content:
A  y/o male/female has past history of 

presented with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech.

Smoking(-), Alcohol (-)
[Patient baseline status] GCS, pre-Stroke mRS:0
LKNT: 10/20 08:00
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6
Language: [e.g., no aphasia / mild expressive aphasia]
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
no facial palsy
Motor:
 - upper proximal (R/L: [5/5]), upper distal (R/L: [5/5])
 - lower proximal (R/L: [5/5]), lower distal (R/L: [5/5])
DTR: C5(R/L): ++/++, C6(R/L): ++/++, C7(R/L): ++/++, L4(R/L): ++/++, S1(R/L): ++/++
Babinski sign: R/L: down/down
Sensory: pin prick intact
FNF: no dysmetria, gait: no ataxia
Associated symptoms: no nausea/vomiting, no nystagmus, no dysarthria, no dysphagia, no diplopia, no hearing impairment, no tinnitus

ER NIHSS: 000 000 0000 00000 = 0

Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage or definite acute infarction seen

Impression:
# Acute left/right subcortical infarction

Suggestion:
# Acute Stroke Management:
 - rtPA thrombolysis is not indicated (over time window)
 - EVT is not indicated due to no LVO
 - Aspirin 3#STAT and 1#QD PO, Clopidogrel 4#STAT and 1#QD PO 
 - IV hydration N/S
# We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, and reminded them about the red-flag sign. Please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs before admission.
# Admission

title: Status epilepticus with GTCS
content:
This 40 y/o male has past history
# Hypertension without medical control
在家全身抽蓄雙眼上吊，發作10分鐘自行逐漸恢復，現意識清楚，第二次發作
第一次為今年8月在沖繩旅遊時
According to his family, he had convulsion over all extremities with bilateral eyes upper gazing for about 10 minutes today. 
Cold sweating was also noted. He denied any prior history of seizures, head trauma, stroke, or other neurological conditions.
His consciousness gradually improved on the ambulance with mild post-ictal confusion and nausea sensation, and had fully returned to baseline when he came to the ER.
This was his seond time seizure.
He denied any medication use. He had head trauma once at 2025/08 in Okinawa when he had his first time seizure.
He drinks a bottle of red wine per day for insomnia relief without remarkable increasing or decreasing amount recently. 
He denied febrile convulsion history, seizure-associated family history or past history.

According to his family, he experienced a convulsion involving all extremities with bilateral upward eye gazing for about 10 minutes when having dinner today. He denies any prior history of seizures, head trauma, stroke, or other neurological conditions. His consciousness gradually improved on the ambulance with mild post-ictal confusion and a sensation of nausea, and had fully returned to his baseline when he arrived at the ER.
This was his second time experiencing a seizure.
He denies fever, infection, stress or any current medication use. He reported a history of head trauma once in 2025/08 in Okinawa, which was when he had his first seizure.
He drinks a bottle of red wine per day for insomnia relief, with no remarkable recent increase or decrease in the amount.
He denies a history of febrile convulsions, a family history of seizures, or any other pertinent past medical history.

Lab data showed Ammonia 99, GOT(AST) 278, Bilirubin T 1.3, GPT(ALT) 166, Lipase 83, WBC 11.86
Brain CT scan: no ICH or remarkable lesion noted

[NE]
Consciousness:E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM:full,pupil(R/L:2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
Motor: upper (R/L:5/5),lower (R/L:5/5)
DTR: L4(R/L):++/++
no dysarthria, no dysphagia,
no diplopia, no hearing impairment,no tinnitus 

Impression:
# Recurrent convulsive status epilepticus, secondary to suspected hyperammonemia or hepatic dysfunction
# Acute hepatocellular Injury, probably alcohol-related

Suggestion:
# Keppra 1000mg STAT + 500mg Q12H IVD
# We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, and reminded them about the red flag sign.
# Admission (#11294)

title: TIA
content:
A 43 y/o male who denied any underlying disease.
He had sudden left sided weakness at 10/10 18:30. He denied nausea or vomiting, numbness, headache, loss of conscious, blurred vision, slurred speech, facial palsy, or head trauma. The weakness was totally recovered after 15 minutes.
He also mentioned intermitent tension headache within one week. The headache ocurred once a day, with duration of 20-30 minutes, and mainly during his sleeping time. He denied nausea or vomiting, visual or hearing abnormalities.

LKNT: 10/10 18:30
[Patient baseline status] GCS456, pre-Stroke mRS:0
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert 
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
facial palsy (-)
Motor:
 - upper proximal (R/L: [5/5])
 - lower proximal (R/L: [5/5])
DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
Babinski sign: R/L: down/down
Sensory: intact
FNF: no dysmetria
NIHSS = 0

Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage or definite acute infarction seen

Impression:
TIA, ABCD2=3

Suggestion:
# Aspirin 3# STAT+1# QD
# Suggest Admission but patient tend to AAD
# We have explained the clinical coarse to the patient, and reminded him to warn about the red flag sign and high risk of stroke

title: Herpes zoster
content:
A 39 y/o male who has underlying disease of asthma.
He had frequent flu in recent months with more stressed work.
He had right headache for 3 days and vesicle over right forehead since yesteray.
Associated symptoms included right eye pain with tearing. He denied blurred vision, vomiting, fever, no hearing impairment.
He was refered from neuor opd for admission and consult ophthalmologist.
HZO with blepharoconjunctivitis OD was diagnosed.

[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert 
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
Visual field: intact
No visual impairment, no hearing impairment
facial palsy (-)
Sensory: intact
Hurchinson sign: equivocal
Ramsonhunt sign: negative

vesicles near right eye

Impression:
Herpes zoster over right CNV1 with right blepharoconjunctivitis

Suggestion:
# Pain control
# Acyclovir 1000mg Q8H
# Hydration N/S 40mL/hr and check renal function
# Suggest Admission (#09182)
# We have explained the clinical coarse to the patient, and reminded him to warn about the red flag sign

title: Left VN
content:
This 56 y/o female without known underlying. She had sudden dizziness this 12:00PM with vomiting, mild headache and general weakness. This is her first time dizziness episode. She had unsteady gait without deviation to specific side. She had chronic headache problem but totally improved around 5 years ago. She denied blurred vision, hearing impairment, slurred speech, LOC, fever or recent head truama.

[NE]
Consciousness:E4V5M6
Language:no aphasia
EOM:full,pupil(R/L:2.5mm+/2.5mm+)
Motor: upper (R/L:5/5); lower (R/L:5/5)
Nystagmus: Right-beating nystagmus following Second-degree Alexander's law
Sensory:intact, FNF:no dysmetria, Romberg:(-)
no dysarthria, no dysphagia, no facial palsy, no diplopia, no hearing impairment, no tinnitus, no meningeal signs, no neck stiffness
Brain CT scan: no ICH or remarkable lesion noted 

Impression:
Left vestibular neuritis

Suggestion:
1. Symptomatic treatment, Dinidol 1#TID PO
2. Mepron STAT + Compesolon 6# BID
3. We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, and remind to go back to ER if red flag signs present
4. Neuro OPD f/u

title: Lecanimab 自費同意書價格
content:
Leqembi 200mg/vial 贈藥 $ 13000
Diphenhydramine $ 20
Acetal(acetaminophen) 500mg/tab $ 1
Normal saline $ 37

A 74 y/o Female has past history of
Hypertension, DM, Arrhythmia (under regular control at NTUH)
T2-T3 and Lumbar spine stenosis diagnosed 10 years ago with chronic lower limb weakness (surgery was suggested but refused)
She visited our OPD 3 days ago due to right lower limb weakness. At that time, stroke was considered unlikely. However, she complained of worsening weakness over the right leg and subjective difficulty in speech at home. She denied fever, nausea/vomiting, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
LKNT: Unclear (chronic/subacute)
pre-Stroke mRS: 1
Examination:
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
Facial palsy (-)
Dysarthria (-)
Dysphagia (-)
Motor:
 * upper proximal (R/L: 5/5), upper distal (R/L: 5/5)
 * lower proximal (R/L: 4+/5), lower distal (R/L: 4+/5)
   DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
   Babinski sign: R/L: negative
   Sensory: intact
ER NIHSS: 0
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Impression:
Right lower limb weakness, suspect spinal stenosis related or psychosomatic (anxiety).
Acute stroke is unlikely.
Suggestion:
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Neuro OPD follow up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

This 70 y/o male has past history of
Alcoholism (abstained)
Liver cirrhosis under GI OPD follow-up
Traumatic ICH s/p op (1 year ago)
According to the family, the patient has had recurrent episodes of drowsiness lasting 2-3 days with poor oral intake and voiding since the operation. A similar episode recurred since last Friday. Tonight, he complained of mild weakness and dizziness at the parking lot. Subsequently, he was found to have a loss of consciousness accompanied by upward gazing, foaming at the mouth, and generalized convulsions. The duration was about 5 minutes. Post-ictal confusion was noted in the ER.
She denied dizziness, weakness, nausea/vomiting, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert (recovered at consultation)
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
No facial palsy.
Motor: upper (R/L: 5/5), lower (R/L: 5/5)
DTR: L4(R/L): +++/++
No dysarthria, dysphagia, or diplopia.
Lab data: Ammonia 356, pH acidic, Lactate elevated.
Brain CT scan: Old ICH with encephalomalacia; no new ICH.
Impression:
Symptomatic GTC Seizure
Hyperammonemia (Hepatic Encephalopathy)
Old Traumatic ICH sequelae
Suggestion:
 * Keppra 1000mg IVD STAT and 500mg Q12H.
 * Correct hyperammonemia and acidosis (ER/Internal Medicine).
 * We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, and reminded them about the red flag sign.
 * Suggest Neurology and GI OPD follow up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 59 y/o female has past history of
ESRD on CAPD
s/p living kidney transplant in 2022
Hypertension, Type 2 DM
Mild dementia (CDR 0.5)
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)
Since last week (12/04-12/05), she has presented with progressive unsteady gait (small steps) and poor interaction. Associated symptoms included intermittent vocal outbursts ("ah" sounds) during sleep or rest, and back weakness with difficulty standing from a sitting position (requiring assistance). The symptoms fluctuated with mild improvement noted on 12/07-12/08. A similar episode occurred in August, which improved after CSF drainage. She denied auditory or visual hallucinations, agitation, fever, or recent trauma.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Mentation: Oriented to person, place, and time.
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
Motor: upper (R/L: 5/5), lower (R/L: 5/5)
DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
Babinski sign: R/L: down/down
Brain CT scan: (Not provided, previous history of NPH)
Impression:
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH), suspected recurrence
Mild dementia
Constipation
Suggestion:
Arrange admission to 9B ward for CSF drainage (Tap test) and medication adjustment.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 50 y/o female has past history of
Migraine
Old CVA (Right subcortical infarction s/p r-tPA in 2021)
She visited our ER 2 days ago (12/10) due to left-sided weakness and dysarthria, which recovered spontaneously (Impression: TIA). She declined admission at that time.
Today, she presented again with persistent mild choking sensation (subjective dysphagia), left cheek numbness (localized), left blurred vision and tinnitus.
She denied dizziness, nausea, or vomiting.
LKNT: [Fluctuating course since 12/10]
Patient baseline status: Alert, independent.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
Nystagmus: negative
Facial palsy: (-)
Dysarthria: (-)
Dysphagia: subjective complaint, but swallowing function intact on exam.
Visual field: intact, though subjective blurred vision over left eye.
Motor:
 * upper proximal (R/L: 5/5), upper distal (R/L: 5/5)
 * lower proximal (R/L: 5/5), lower distal (R/L: 5/5)
   DTR: L4(R/L): +++/+++
   Babinski sign: R/L: negative
   Sensory: Left cheek numbness (localized).
ER NIHSS: 0 (or minor based on sensory)
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Impression:
Recurrent TIA / Minor stroke, with symptom progression.
R/O Acute infarction.
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * Aspirin 1# QD (continue).
 * Clopidogrel 4# STAT + 1# QD.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Admission to Neurology ward.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 66 y/o Female has past history of
 * No underlying disease. Recent health check-up showed normal results.
The patient was in her normal self last night at 23:00 (LKNT). This morning at 06:50, she was found lying in the kitchen. She was unable to speak or interact appropriately, though her eyes were open. Some limb trembling was noted, which family described as "trying to lift hands but weak" rather than typical sustained tonic-clonic convulsion.
 * She denied nausea or vomiting, head trauma, or incontinence.
 * In ER, her motor power improved to >4 and GCS recovered to E4V4M6.
Examination:
Consciousness: E4V4M6, alert.
Language: Aphasia (+) with irrelevant answers.
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2mm+/2mm+).
facial palsy (-). Tongue deviation (-).
Dysarthria (-).
Dysphagia (-).
Motor:
 * upper (R/L: [4+/4+])
 * lower (R/L: [4/4])
   DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++.
   Babinski sign: R/L: down/down.
   Sensory: symmetric response to pinprick (verbal expression limited by aphasia).
ER NIHSS: 4.
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Lab data: No remarkable abnormality.
Impression:
Suspected acute ischemic stroke presenting with aphasia.
r/o Post-ictal confusion.
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * Aspirin + Clopidogrel (DAPT) loading.
 * IV hydration N/S.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Keep observation at ER until 12:00 to monitor for clinical fluctuation or recovery.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 76 y/o male has past history of
Hypertension
Pituitary tumor s/p operation in 2019 at Shuang Ho Hospital
Presented with sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech at 09:40 this morning. He was sent to our ER by ambulance.
He denied dizziness, nausea/vomiting, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
LKNT: 09:40 AM
Baseline: Independent
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM: Left gaze limitation noted, pupil (R/L: 2mm+/2mm+)
Dysarthria (+, mild)
Dysphagia (-)
Motor:
 * upper (R/L: 5/4)
 * lower (R/L: 5/5)
   DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
   Babinski sign: R/L: negative
   Sensory: Left face and left hand numbness
   FNF: right no dysmetria; left suspected dysmetria (related to weakness)
   Heel-to-shin: bilateral intact
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Brain MRI for EVT: No LVO noted.
Impression:
Acute ischemic stroke with left hemiparesis and gaze limitation.
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * IV rtPA thrombolysis was administered due to onset within 4.5 hours.
 * EVT was not indicated due to no LVO.
 * IV hydration N/S.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Arrange ICU admission.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 76 y/o male has past history of Hypotension.
He presented with sudden falling backward while walking, accompanied by transient loss of consciousness for seconds.
The consciousness recovered to his baseline status spontaneously.
At ER, he initially presented with repetitive questioning and short-term memory loss (asking "Where am I?"), which had totally resolved during our bedside evaluation.
He stated similar episodes occurred 4-5 times (last time 3 months ago), usually triggered by post-prandial state or walking, with rapid recovery.
He denied muscle convulsion, urinary incontinence, nausea or vomiting.
Examination:
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert.
Language: no aphasia.
EOM: full. Nystagmus: (-).
Facial palsy (-).
Motor: upper (R/L: [5/5]); lower (R/L: [5/5]).
DTR: L4(R/L): [++/++].
Babinski sign: R/L: [down/down].
Sensory: intact.
FNF: no dysmetria.
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage or remarkable lesion noted.
Impression:
Syncope, suspected vasovagal syncope.
Seizure is unlikely.
Suggestion:
Keep observation for 4-6 hours.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Discharge if stable with Neuro OPD follow up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 88 y/o female has past history of
DM, Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia, and Valvular heart disease (followed at Cheng Hsin General Hospital).
She is currently under Clopidogrel use.
This morning, the caregiver noted the patient had right facial palsy accompanied by drooling. She also complained of body numbness and dizziness. Upon arrival at our ER, the facial palsy and drooling had almost fully resolved.
Regarding the numbness, she described it as bilateral distal weakness involving hands (forearm to fingers) and legs (knee to ankle), which has persisted for over a year. The dizziness is also chronic and intermittent.
She denied nausea, vomiting, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
LKNT: This morning.
Patient baseline status: Independent.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 2mm+/2mm+), No nystagmus.
No facial palsy.
No facial numbness.
Dysarthria (-).
Dysphagia (-).
Tongue deviation (-).
Motor:
 * upper proximal (R/L: 4+/4+), upper distal (R/L: 4+/4+)
 * lower proximal (R/L: 4+/4+), lower distal (R/L: 4+/4+)
   DTR: L4(R/L): +/+.
   Babinski sign: R/L: down/down (flexion).
   Sensory: intact (Face); Chronic numbness over distal extremities.
   FNF: no dysmetria.
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Impression:
TIA, ABCD2 score = 4.
Chronic peripheral neuropathy.
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * Anti-platelet: Add Aspirin 1# STAT + 1# QD (DAPT with underlying Clopidogrel).
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Keep observation. If stable, discharge with Neuro OPD follow up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 56 y/o female has past history of
Lung cancer (followed at Taipei VGH)
The patient presented with sudden onset of left distal limb numbness (involving palm, upper arm, sole, and calf) since 15:00. The symptoms spontaneously recovered to baseline after 2 hours but recurred at night. Left facial numbness was also mentioned but recovered fully.
She denied dizziness, weakness, nausea/vomiting, dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
LKNT: 15:00
Patient baseline status: Independent.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert
Language: no aphasia
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
Facial palsy (-)
Dysarthria (-)
Dysphagia (-)
Motor:
 * upper proximal (R/L: 5/5), upper distal (R/L: 5/5)
 * lower proximal (R/L: 5/5), lower distal (R/L: 5/5)
   DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++
   Babinski sign: R/L: down/down
   Sensory: Subjective numbness over left distal extremities, currently recovered.
   FNF: no dysmetria
ER NIHSS: 0
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage seen.
Impression:
TIA, r/o minor stroke
Lung cancer
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * IV hydration N/S.
 * Keep observation at ER.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
If the condition remains stable with improvement by tomorrow morning, discharge is allowed with Neuro OPD follow-up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

This 77 y/o male has past history of Gastric disorder, Insomnia, and chronic hoarseness (> 30 years).
Since 12/12, he has experienced dizziness and drowsiness, accompanied by falling episodes. He had been taking cold medications (including antihistamines) for 3 days due to flu-like symptoms. He suffered a fall with mild head contusion today (12/14).
He denied focal weakness, nausea, vomiting, acute dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia, or tinnitus.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
Consciousness: E4V5M6, alert.
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+).
Nystagmus: negative.
Cranial Nerve: Tongue deviation to the left was noted, but likely due to dental status (edentulous on the right side); tongue power was symmetric and could deviate to the right normally.
Motor: upper (R/L: 5/5); lower (R/L: 5/5).
DTR: L4(R/L): ++/++.
Babinski sign: R/L: down/down.
Sensory: intact.
FNF: no dysmetria. Heel-knee-shin: no dysmetria.
Romberg: negative.
Gait: Slow but steady. No truncal ataxia.
Brain CT scan: Old infarct at right thalamus. No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Impression:
Dizziness and drowsiness, suspected cold medication-related side effect.
Old right thalamic infarction.
Suggestion:
 * Aspirin 1# QD PO.
 * We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
 * The family declined admission for Brain MRI stroke survey.
 * Discharge with Neuro OPD follow-up on 12/15.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 65 y/o male has past history of Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Tardive Dyskinesia, and Parkinson's Disease.
 * History: He underwent Gamma Knife radiosurgery at our hospital in November for severe left leg resting tremor and dyskinesia (abnormal foot inversion affecting gait).
 * HPI: He has been under regular Madopa 125mg control with stable status until 12/14 morning.
 * Symptoms: He presented with worsening resting tremor. The tremor progressed from the left leg to involve the right leg, bilateral hands, and body (legs > hands/body).
 * Alleviating factors: The patient reported that taking an additional 0.5 tablet of Madopa alleviated the symptoms.
 * Denials: He denied fever, recent head trauma, nausea or vomiting, headache, limb weakness, numbness, diarrhea, constipation, or new medication use.
[Focused Neurological Examination]
 * Consciousness: E4V5M6, clear.
 * Cranial Nerves:
   * EOM: Full.
   * Facial palsy: (-).
   * Tongue: Mild tremor (+), no deviation.
 * Motor: upper (R/L: [5/5]), lower (R/L: [5/5]).
 * Tremor: Resting tremor noted over bilateral legs and hands.
 * Tone: No rigidity or spasticity. No active dyskinesia observed.
 * DTR: L4(R/L): [++/++].
 * Babinski sign: R/L: [down/down].
Workup:
 * Brain CT and Lab data were arranged to rule out intracranial hemorrhage, infection, or electrolyte/metabolic imbalance.
Impression:
Parkinson's disease with acute worsening of resting tremor.
Rule out metabolic encephalopathy or electrolyte imbalance.
Suggestion:
Wait for Lab and CT results to exclude acute medical causes (infection/ICH/metabolic).
If acute medical causes are excluded, consider adjustment of anti-Parkinson agents.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Suggest Neurology OPD follow up.
Resident S-H Wang (#2545)

A 82 y/o female has past history of
Hypothyroidism, Atrial Fibrillation (AF), Hypertension.
She has been on Warfarin for AF.
On 12/17 18:30, she presented with sudden onset right-sided weakness while having dinner.
Associated symptoms included aphasia ("speechless") and a vacant stare.
She denied dizziness, nausea/vomiting, dysphagia, diplopia, hearing impairment or tinnitus.
LKNT: 12/17 18:30.
Consciousness: E4V2M5, staring.
Language: Global aphasia.
EOM: full, pupil (R/L: 3mm+/3mm+)
facial palsy (-).
Motor:
 * upper (R/L: [2/4+])
 * lower (R/L: [2/4+])
   DTR: L4(R/L): +++/+++.
   Babinski sign: R (+).
   Sensory: intact.
ER NIHSS: 17.
Imaging Findings:
Brain CT scan: No acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Brain MRI for EVT: Left distal M1 occlusion.
Impression:
Acute ischemic stroke with Left distal M1 occlusion.
Cardioembolic stroke.
Suggestion:
Acute Stroke Management:
 * Lab data showed INR 1.28. IV rtPA thrombolysis was administered (slow push).
 * EVT was indicated due to LVO (Left distal M1). The family agreed to the procedure.
 * IV hydration N/S.
We have explained the clinical course to the family and the patient, please keep f/u clinical symptoms and signs.
Admission to ICU for post-EVT care.
